additionalTextInformation.text:
The allegory employed in the landscape is also evident in the representation of the city, which is shown bathed in light in the background and alludes to the heavenly city of Jerusalem. Similarly the scene of ‘The Brazen Serpent' integrated into the landscape provides a prototype for the sacrifice made  for man's salvation and the resurrection. Ribestein probably drew on Early Netherlandish iconographic tradition for this landscape charged with salvation-historical motifs, like Joachim Patinirs. However, the landscape and the tonality also show parallels with contemporary Dutch and Flemish art (The Crucifixion, Marten de Vos, in Celle Castle) and a direct influence may be assumed. 
[Maria Dieters, Exhib. Cat. Berlin 2009, 270, No. VIII.11]

pageContext.description:
Here the artist has replaced his former insignia 'Ribestein' with a heraldic shield bearing the initials 'MR' in front of a column and it is positioned at the feet of St John the Baptist. The painting draws on motifs from an earlier epitaph by Ribestein (the so-called Reiche-Epitaph) and varies them. In the earlier work it is the inscription that enables us to interpret the Crucifixion within the context of Luther's doctrine of Law and Grace, whereas in the present panel the large figures of Moses and St John beneath the cross as well as the scenes in the background serve this purpose. In both paintings the cross, which is central to Christian faith is shifted to the front edge of the painting. [...] On this panel the frontal depiction of Christ with open eyes shows him triumphant over death.
It is striking that Ribestein abandons the medieval conventions  of the epitaph painting and places the donor family behind the cross and as such removes them the material world. This alone is enough to indicate that the landscape is more than a mere backdrop.  
[Maria Dieters, Exhib. Cat. Berlin 2009, 270, 271, No. VIII.11]
